texts.definition: Gameplay where players social abilities affect how well they succeed with their actions.
markups: <style="Definition">Gameplay where players social abilities affect how well they succeed with their actions.</style>

While many games have strict rules for how actions are performed, others have actions where how well the actions are performed depend more on how they are perceived by other players they are interacting with. In the latter case, players' <style="CurrentLink">Social Skills</style> become

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Strategy%20Games">Strategy Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diplomacy">Diplomacy</link></style> and to a lesser degree <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization">Civilization</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/History%20of%20the%20World">History of the World</link></style> depend on players abilities to create alliances and potentially lure other players to trust them. Other games depending strongly on players' ability to influence each other include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Intrigue">Intrigue</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/So%20Long%20Sucker">So Long Sucker</link></style>. Less aggressive, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Container">Container</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Settlers%20of%20Catan">Settlers of Catan</link></style> are examples where players' <style="CurrentLink">Social Skills</style> are put to test in negotiation trades with other players.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Roleplaying%20Games">Roleplaying Games</link></style> let players enact and roleplay characters in fictive worlds, and doing this typically require <style="CurrentLink">Social Skills</style>. This can be found both in tabletop version, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fiasco">Fiasco</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Paranoia">Paranoia</link></style>, and live action versions, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Conspiracy%20for%20Good">Conspiracy for Good</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Monitor%20Celestra">Monitor Celestra</link></style>.

That a game is a <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Game</link></style> is a necessary but not sufficient requirement for <style="CurrentLink">Social Skills</style> to be present in a game design. The presence of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Alliances">Alliances</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Guilds">Guilds</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="parties">Parties</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Organizations">Social Organizations</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> makes <style="CurrentLink">Social Skills</style> very likely to appear although not always for influencing gameplay.

Many gameplay activities in games rely on <style="CurrentLink">Social Skills</style>. <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Coordination">Coordination</link></style> are generic activities that do so, even if players may not be performing purely social actions to display <style="CurrentLink">Social Skills</style> but can do so only by playing competently. Some, e.g. <style="Link"><link="bluffing">Bluffing</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="guilting">Guilting</link></style>, require <style="CurrentLink">Social Skills</style> while players may have advantages in others, e.g. <style="Link"><link="betting">Betting</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="bidding">Bidding</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="trading">Trading</link></style> and being <style="Link"><link="coaches">Coaches</link></style>, if they have good <style="CurrentLink">Social Skills</style>, and displays of them are therefore likely to occur in these activities as well. The creation of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Temporary%20Alliances">Temporary Alliances</link></style> and maintenance of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Uncommitted%20Alliances">Uncommitted Alliances</link></style> are examples of gameplay activities that rely on <style="CurrentLink">Social Skills</style>. Both <style="Link"><link="enactment">Enactment</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style> can be done in <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style>, but performing them in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> typically requires <style="CurrentLink">Social Skills</style>. Games with <style="Link"><link="social-roles">Social Roles</link></style> often rely on <style="CurrentLink">Social Skills</style> but negotiating which players should have which role can require <style="CurrentLink">Social Skills</style> as well.

Any use of <style="CurrentLink">Social Skills</style> in unmediated situations can both require more requiring and be more efficient, so <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Unmediated%20Social%20Interaction">Unmediated Social Interaction</link></style> modifies how <style="CurrentLink">Social Skills</style> function in a game. Likewise, enforced or possible <style="Link"><link="player-player-proximity">Player-Player Proximity</link></style> will affect <style="CurrentLink">Social Skills</style> in a game.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diegetic%20Social%20Maintenance">Diegetic Social Maintenance</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diegetic%20Social%20Norms">Diegetic Social Norms</link></style> are two patterns that require the use of <style="CurrentLink">Social Skills</style> in the diegesis rather than between players. Thus, these can be used to instantiate <style="CurrentLink">Social Skills</style>.

The requirement of <style="CurrentLink">Social Skills</style> in a game can both be a source of <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> for players and be an area of expertise in which one can show <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style>. Since displaying <style="CurrentLink">Social Skills</style> can be appreciated for its own sake besides what gameplay effects it has, it can be a source for <style="Link"><link="social-rewards">Social Rewards</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="betting">Betting</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="bidding">Bidding</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="bluffing">Bluffing</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="coaches">Coaches</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="cooperation">Cooperation</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Coordination">Coordination</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diegetic%20Social%20Maintenance">Diegetic Social Maintenance</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diegetic%20Social%20Norms">Diegetic Social Norms</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="enactment">Enactment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="guilting">Guilting</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="social-roles">Social Roles</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="trading">Trading</link></style>
